author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The C.D.C. stands by a decision not to require testing to leave isolation.
description: Despite sharp criticism, the agency is holding to its guidance that  people infected with the coronavirus can stop isolating after five days without obtaining a negative virus test.
content: Despite sharp criticism, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Tuesday stood by its recommendation that Americans infected with the coronavirus end their isolation after five days without first obtaining a negative virus test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Luzzi
title: Tackling the Enduring Mysteries of Dante’s Life
description: “Dante: A Life,” an impressively researched new portrait by the Italian novelist and historian Alessandro Barbero, plumbs some of the perennial riddles in Dante studies and arrives at unconventional conclusions.
content: DANTEA LifeBy Alessandro BarberoTranslated by Allan Cameron
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC and Russia agree to increase oil output amid lagging production.
description: The group called OPEC Plus decided to increase oil output by 400,000 barrels a day, but its members have lately been falling short of production quotas.
content: Officials from OPEC, Russia and other oil producers agreed on Tuesday to continue their program of gradual monthly output increases in February, bolstering output by 400,000 barrels a day, but there are growing doubts about whether they can deliver on the additional barrels.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: When 3 Shots Don’t Do the Trick, Some Try 4 or 5
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 4, 2022.
content: “Rather than say, ‘Shame on them,’ I would say, ‘Shame on the system we’ve created.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: The Unsung Heroes of the 2020 Presidential Election
description: “The Steal,” by Mark Bowden and Matthew Teague, memorializes those brave Republicans who defied their party and refused to overturn the 2020 election.
content: THE STEALThe Attempt to Overturn the 2020 Election and the People Who Stopped It
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
title: Cuomo Will Not Be Prosecuted in Groping Case, Albany D.A. Says
description: The district attorney described the woman who said former Gov. Andrew Cuomo had groped her as “credible,” but added that proving her allegation would be difficult.
content: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York will not be prosecuted in the criminal case involving allegations that he groped a former aide in the Executive Mansion in 2020, the Albany County district attorney announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: What happens next to Elizabeth Holmes.
description: Convicted of four of 11 charges of fraud, Ms. Holmes can appeal her conviction.
content: Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, now awaits sentencing after being found guilty of four of 11 charges of fraud on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: To Boldly Explore the Jewish Roots of ‘Star Trek’
description: An exhibition at a Jewish cultural center has plenty of artifacts to delight Trekkies — but it also notes the Jewish origins of the Vulcan salute.
content: LOS ANGELES — Adam Nimoy gazed across a museum gallery filled with “Star Trek” stage sets, starship replicas, space aliens, fading costumes and props (think phaser, set to stun). The sounds of a beam-me-up transporter wafted across the room. Over his shoulder, a wall was filled with an enormous photograph of his father — Leonard Nimoy, who played Spock on the show — dressed in his Starfleet uniform, his fingers splayed in the familiar Vulcan “live long and prosper” greeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla opens a dealership in Xinjiang, drawing accusations it’s helping China ‘cover up genocide.’
description: Senator Marco Rubio criticized the electric carmaker for opening the outlet in a region where China has been accused of targeting Muslims.
content: Tesla came under fire from political leaders and human rights groups Tuesday after announcing it would open a dealership in the Xinjiang region, where China is accused of detaining hundreds of thousands of Muslims in indoctrination camps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Stewart
title: In New Orleans, King Cake Is a Way to Make Joy
description: The colorful cake is more than a dessert — it’s the flavor of the city. And a diverse community of bakers are adapting the Carnival specialty to their own tastes.
content: NEW ORLEANS — When Dominick Lee was in elementary school in the 1990s, every year for Twelfth Night, the teacher would bring a king cake for the class to share. He and his classmates would wait for their slices — decorated with purple, gold and green sugars — eager to see which piece had a tiny plastic baby hidden inside. Whoever found it was responsible for bringing another king cake to school the next week, and the cycle would continue through Carnival season, right up until Mardi Gras.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Hollywood Glamour Is Pandemic-Proof at the Polo Lounge
description: A clubby gathering spot attracts a who’s who of the film industry, and reminds them of a time when movies were still king.
content: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood is down in the dumps. Oscar hopefuls like “King Richard,” “Nightmare Alley” and “West Side Story” have sputtered, and everyone knows that, studio spin aside, the Omicron variant is only partly to blame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Were You Hospitalized in New York City With Covid? Tell Us About It.
description: Times reporters writing about the most recent surge would like to hear from people who were hospitalized with Covid-19 in the last two weeks.
content: As hospitalizations continue to rise, New York Times reporters are looking to speak with people or family members of people who have recently been hospitalized with Covid-19 in the New York City area to hear about their experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Hong Kong expands its vaccine requirements as it fights to control Omicron.
description: Hong Kong residents must have at least one coronavirus vaccine shot to enter restaurants beginning late next month, Carrie Lam, the city’s chief executive, said on Tuesday, as the city races to stamp out the spread of the Omicron variant.
content: Hong Kong residents must have at least one coronavirus vaccine shot to enter restaurants beginning late next month, Carrie Lam, the city’s chief executive, said on Tuesday, as the city races to stamp out the spread of the Omicron variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christie Aschwanden
title: Is It Possible to Exercise Too Much?
description: And if so, how can I tell if I’m overdoing it?
content: Q: I hike seven miles per day, spend five to six hours per week in vigorous fitness exercise, and about four hours per week performing heavy resistance training. Is it possible to exercise too much? And how much is too much?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Haiti Prime Minister Survives Assassination Attempt, His Office Says
description: Prime Minister Ariel Henry was the target of an unsuccessful attempt on his life over the weekend by gunmen in the northern city of Gonaïves, his office said Monday night.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE — Gunmen unsuccessfully attempted to assassinate Prime Minister Ariel Henry of Haiti during an event on Saturday commemorating the Caribbean country’s independence, his office said in a statement on Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Sweden’s king and queen test positive for the coronavirus.
description: King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden and Queen Silvia, his wife, tested positive for the coronavirus on Monday evening, the Swedish Royal Court said in a statement Tuesday.
content: King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden and Queen Silvia, his wife, tested positive for the coronavirus on Monday evening, the Swedish Royal Court said in a statement Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Should You Even Bother With Resolutions This Year?
description: Contrary to conventional wisdom, resolutions can work when done right. But  it seems many more Americans than usual plan to sit this year out.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: A Widening Web of Undersea Cables Connects Britain to Green Energy
description: Linking one nation’s power grid with another’s is considered essential as more electricity is generated from solar and wind.
content: BLYTH, England — Britain’s economic and political ties to Europe may be fraying, but a growing web of undersea electrical cables binds the nation’s vital power system and its clean energy aspirations to the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Take a Look at the Inspirations Behind ‘The Witcher’
description: The showrunner of the wildly popular Netflix fantasy series offers a tour through the images and themes that have guided her.
content: Netflix’s wildly popular series “The Witcher” has everything you could want from a fantasy adventure, including terrifying beasts, magical feats, sword battles and power plays. In the first season, we watched as the destinies of the title character, a monster hunter named Geralt of Rivia (Henry Cavill), became inextricably linked with that of the tormented sorceress Yennefer of Vengerberg (Anya Chalotra) and the young princess Cirilla (Freya Allan) — whose role and powers begin to emerge in the long-awaited Season 2, which was unveiled on Dec. 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Idra Novey
title: Craving Books, Sex and Revolution
description: Gina Apostol’s novel “Bibliolepsy” revisits the final years of the Marcos dictatorship in the Philippines.
content: BIBLIOLEPSYBy Gina Apostol
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diana Tsui
title: With His New Line, Joseph Altuzarra Honors His Teen Self
description: For the designer, Altu is not just gender neutral but also a deeply personal project many years in the making.
content: Like many New Yorkers during the city’s lockdown of 2020, Joseph Altuzarra discovered that being at home for such an extended period led to much introspection. Even before March of that year, though, life as he knew it had changed drastically, as the fashion designer and his husband, the real estate investor Seth Weissman, welcomed their first child, Emma, at the end of 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Nobody Is Stepping Up at Twitter
description: Rule breakers just claim censorship, censorship, censorship.
content: Alex Jones deserved it. Donald Trump really deserved it. And now Marjorie Taylor Greene? She double deserves it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By S. Kirk Walsh
title: Are Children the Future? In This Novel, the Answer Is Complicated.
description: In “Anthem,” Noah Hawley ushers readers into a nightmarish fantasy world.
content: ANTHEMBy Noah Hawley
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Eric Adams defends his pandemic response as N.Y.C. virus cases surge.
description: Eric Adams, who took office as mayor on Saturday, enthusiastically backs keeping public schools open and has urged companies not to let their workers work remotely.
content: In his first big test as mayor of New York City, Eric Adams is resisting pressure from municipal unions and elected officials to do more to stop the spread of the coronavirus as cases and hospitalizations are surging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus and Luke Broadwater
title: The Capitol Police and the Scars of Jan. 6
description: For many officers, their bodies, minds and lives will never be the same after the attack.
content: On the morning of Jan. 6, Caroline Edwards, a 31-year-old United States Capitol Police officer, was stationed by some stairs on the Capitol grounds when the energy of the crowd in front of her seemed to take on a different shape; it was like that moment when rain suddenly becomes hail. A loud, sour-sounding horn bleated, piercing through the noise of the crowd, whose cries coalesced into an accusatory chant: “U.S.A.! U.S.A.!” Edwards, who is 5-foot-4, tried to make herself look imposing. Behind a row of bike racks, alongside four other officers, she stood in a wide stance, her hands on her hips. A man in front of her whipped off his jacket as if he were getting ready for something, flipped his red MAGA hat backward — and then the rioters were pushing the bike racks forward as the officers pushed back, trying to hold their balance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: How to Design a Home Gym That You’ll Actually Use
description: As the pandemic rages on, the safest place to work out is at home. Here’s how to create a personal gym you’ll want to spend time in.
content: A new year often comes with new resolutions, and for many, those resolutions center on physical fitness. Whether you want to work off all those holiday cookies or stretch your way into a healthier year, a home gym can make that more convenient — and safer, as the pandemic rages on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian and Maia Coleman
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $1.85 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Verizon and AT&T Agree to Delay 5G Plans Over Airline Safety Concerns
description: The companies will wait two weeks and work with the government.
content: Verizon and AT&T said late Monday that they had agreed to delay their deployment of new wireless technology for two weeks, giving in to the demands of federal aviation regulators who have raised concerns that the signals could create an airline safety hazard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zanele Mji and Lynsey Chutel
title: Mystery Deepens as Suspect Is Charged in South Africa Parliament Fire
description: The man was also accused of possessing explosives, stealing laptops and breaking security laws. Former neighbors were shocked. His lawyer said the government was rushing to find a scapegoat.
content: CAPE TOWN — As a fire that gutted the country’s Parliament buildings was finally extinguished on Tuesday and a bedraggled suspect appeared in court, South Africans were struggling to understand whether the blaze was an act of sabotage, negligence or a simple crime of opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Considering Bone or Joint Surgery? You May Not Need It.
description: For many common problems of the knee, hip, shoulder, spine and wrist, nonsurgical options may be just as good.
content: Considering bone or joint surgery? In many cases, surgery may be no more effective than options like exercise, physical therapy and drug treatments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callan Wink
title: In ‘Velorio,’ Hurricane Survivors Form a New Society. It’s No Paradise.
description: In his debut novel, Xavier Navarro Aquino follows a group of characters who start a utopia in the Puerto Rican mountains after Hurricane Maria.
content: VELORIOBy Xavier Navarro Aquino
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: ‘It’s Chaos’ as Schools Confront Omicron
description: After an unrelenting spike in cases, a small but growing list of districts — including Newark, Atlanta, Milwaukee and Cleveland — moved temporarily to remote learning.
content: The Omicron surge threatens to upend any sense of peace in the nation’s education system.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Chased Her Shamelessly’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: My friend’s annual Christmas card was addressed to “The Perkins Family,” but “The” and “Family” had been crossed out, leaving just my first name, Mary, scrawled above my last. It was a correction that denoted a truth: Unlike most of my friends, I am single. I felt amused and a little sad. The card emphasized what I lacked. But along with my sadness came surprising reassurance: This envelope was a small reminder that I took the road less traveled, that I chose to draw my own life path, that I was OK with living outside the lines. — Mary Perkins
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: As Omicron Bears Down on Retailers, Landlords Get Creative to Fill Space
description: Tenants are being offered concessions like reduced rates and customized spaces, while vacant storefronts are being filled with pop-up shops and works by local artists.
content: In the fall of last year, many retail landlords were breathing a sigh of relief. They had gone all out to fill empty storefronts during the grimmest days of the pandemic, offering concessions to tenants and saying yes to pop-ups. That strategy appeared to pay off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: With Property Sales Plunging, China Evergrande Faces More Protests
description: The developer has tried for months to signal that its $300 billion debt problem was under control. But the challenges keep mounting.
content: Protesters gathered outside China Evergrande offices in Guangzhou on Tuesday to demand that the indebted real estate developer give them their money back, as the company’s sales across China continued to plunge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Toyota Topped G.M. in U.S. Car Sales in 2021, a First for a Foreign Automaker
description: After struggling to produce cars because of a global computer chip shortage, automakers are trying to move quickly to making electric vehicles.
content: Toyota Motor unseated General Motors as the top-selling automaker in the United States last year, becoming the first manufacturer based outside the country to achieve that feat in the industry’s nearly 120-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Neil Vigdor
title: Stranded Drivers Are Freed After 24-Hour Snowy Ordeal on I-95 in Virginia
description: Hundreds were stuck overnight on the interstate south of Washington. A United States senator was among those trapped.
content: Emergency crews on Tuesday afternoon freed the last of hundreds of drivers stranded by a snowstorm on Interstate 95 in Virginia, after more than 24 shivering hours of watching gas gauges drop, rationing food and water and holding out for any kind of help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Sabine Weiss, Last of the ‘Humanist’ Street Photographers, Dies at 97
description: Like Robert Doisneau and Brassaï, she shot life in postwar Paris as it really was. But she also won fame for her reporting and fashion work.
content: Sabine Weiss, whose arresting photographs of dirty-faced children, food-stall vendors and Roma dancers captured the struggles, hopes and occasional moments of humor on the streets of postwar France, died on Dec. 28 at her home in Paris. She was 97 and considered the last member of the humanist school of photography, whose ranks included Robert Doisneau, Brassaï and Willy Ronis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Late Night’ Cancels Shows After Seth Meyers Tests Positive for Coronavirus
description: The NBC host said, “I feel fine,” and that his program would most likely return in a remote format next week.
content: The resurgent pandemic continues to take its toll on the performing arts in New York and to disrupt the late-night comedy programs produced here. On Tuesday, Seth Meyers, the host of NBC’s “Late Night,” said that he had tested positive for the coronavirus and that tapings of his program would be canceled through the end of the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Tracing a Los Angeles Treasure: Its Glorious Sprawl of Sushi
description: Few locales outside Japan can equal the variety, skill and creativity served at the city’s countless sushi counters.
content: LOS ANGELES — “Kinki from Hokkaido,” says Yohei Matsuki, a little muffled through his mask, entrusting you with a piece of seared rockfish nigiri. He won’t bore you with the details, which would take longer to share than this mouthful takes to chew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Prince Andrew’s Uncertain Legal Fate Casts Shadow on Britain’s Royals
description: As Queen Elizabeth II prepares to mark 70 years on the throne this year, a sexual abuse case in a Manhattan court involving her son could mean more turmoil for the royal family.
content: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II will mark 70 years on the throne in February, a milestone unmatched by any British sovereign and a chance to turn the page on three years of ceaseless turmoil in the royal family. But a sexual-abuse lawsuit unfolding in a Manhattan courtroom could yet spoil her celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: American Girl Debuts Chinese American Doll in Response to Anti-Asian Sentiment
description: The company said it created the doll, named Corinne Tan, to teach children to stand against racism.
content: Responding to an increase in anti-Asian sentiment, American Girl has created a Chinese American doll to be its 2022 “Girl of the Year,” to try to teach children to stand against racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Shane Goldmacher
title: As Midterms and 2024 Loom, Trump Political Operation Revs Up
description: The former president is set to headline an event at Mar-a-Lago next month for endorsed candidates and major donors to benefit a supportive super PAC.
content: Donald J. Trump and his allies are scheduling events and raising money for initiatives intended to make the former president a central player in the midterm elections, and possibly to set the stage for another run for the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘American Gadfly’ Review: A Candid Candidacy
description: This documentary goes behind the scenes of Mike Gravel’s oddball run for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination.
content: A victory lap for a campaign that never sought to win, the documentary “American Gadfly” goes a long way toward explaining Mike Gravel’s perplexing run for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Lawsuit Accusing Nirvana of Sexually Exploitive Imagery Is Dismissed
description: Spencer Elden, who was pictured naked as a baby on the cover of “Nevermind,” said Nirvana had engaged in “child pornography.”
content: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit filed by a man who said he had been sexually exploited by the grunge rock group Nirvana when the band used a photo of him as a baby, naked and drifting in a pool, for the cover of its seminal album “Nevermind.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: From the Hockey Rink, a Useful Reminder to Check for Skin Cancer
description: Five tips for spotting melanoma and other skin cancers.
content: In October, Nadia Popovici, a Seattle Kraken hockey fan, went to a game with her parents. She spotted a strange-looking mole on the neck of an assistant equipment manager for the opposing team, the Vancouver Canucks, and typed out a message to him on her phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Dudding
title: Jobs, Omicron, Andrew Cuomo: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Faced With Questions About Forced Labor in China, the I.O.C. Is Tight-Lipped
description: Olympic officials are reluctant to look into whether any Beijing 2022 merchandise might have been made under duress by Uyghurs, an activist group charges.
content: The activists’ request was straightforward: They wanted to share their concerns about human rights in China, in particular the possibility that official merchandise for the Beijing Olympics was being made with forced labor, and to hear what the International Olympic Committee was doing to ensure it was not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Omari Weekes
title: A Novel Punctures the Fantasy of Post-Racial Society
description: In “Phenotypes,” by Paulo Scott, a man who has spent his career examining thorny issues of race returns home to confront a quandary of his own.
content: PHENOTYPESBy Paulo ScottTranslated by Daniel Hahn
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Michael Simon Johnson, Sydney Harper, Paige Cowett, Larissa Anderson, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Corey Schreppel
title: An Investigation Into Flawed Prenatal Tests
description: How screenings for chromosomal abnormalities that promised “peace of mind” instead caused anguish and confusion.
content: About a decade ago, companies in the United States began offering pregnant women noninvasive prenatal testing for chromosomal abnormalities in a fetus, mainly to detect Down syndrome.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Elizabeth Holmes is found guilty on four counts of fraud.
description: Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, was found guilty of four of 11 charges of fraud on Monday.
content: Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, was found guilty of four of 11 charges of fraud on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: Jurors are set to deliver a verdict in Elizabeth Holmes’s fraud trial.
description: The jurors said earlier on Monday that they were deadlocked on three of 11 counts facing Ms. Holmes, but were asked to fill out a verdict form on the other charges.
content: Jurors were set on Monday to deliver a verdict in the fraud trial of Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Is Happy Twitter Booted Marjorie Taylor Greene
description: Seth Meyers said that living in a world with the Republican congresswoman’s “insane” screaming was “like trying to have a conversation with a friend on the street next to a jackhammer.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: In the Capitol’s Shadow, the Jan. 6 Panel Quietly Ramps Up Its Inquiry
description: From a nondescript office building, a few dozen investigators and members of Congress are rushing to dissect what led to the worst attack on the Capitol in centuries.
content: WASHINGTON — Behind closed doors inside a nondescript office building at the foot of Capitol Hill on a recent chilly morning, the House inquiry into the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol was in full swing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Giulia Heyward
title: Colorado Wildfire Inquiry Focuses on Christian Sect
description: Investigators are looking at the possibility that a fire that destroyed more than 900 homes started on property owned by a fundamentalist Christian sect known as Twelve Tribes.
content: Investigators looking into the cause of a colossal wildfire in Colorado that forced the evacuation of tens of thousands of people are focusing on a property owned by a Christian fundamentalist sect, after witnesses reported seeing a structure on fire there moments before the blaze spread with astonishing speed across drought-stricken suburbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: U.S. struggles to avoid Omicron shutdowns.
content: Officials across the U.S., from President Biden on down, have been insisting that they are no longer in the shutdown business and will not order any closures to contain the latest surge in coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden ‘Over-Promised and Under-Delivered’ on Climate. Now, Trouble Looms in 2022.
description: Mounting challenges will make the coming months critical for the president’s environmental agenda, analysts say.
content: WASHINGTON — As the new year opens, President Biden faces an increasingly narrow path to fulfill his ambitious goal of slashing the greenhouse gases generated by the United States that are helping to warm the planet to dangerous levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: My First Times Byline: Anthony Tommasini
description: As he retires after 21 years as the chief classical music critic, Anthony Tommasini reflects on his very first article for The Times: a deeply personal essay about a friend.
content: My first byline for The New York Times, which ran in early February 1988, was an opinion piece that I wish I’d never had to write. Yet, as I retire after 21 years as the chief classical music critic at The Times, I see how much that column prefigured my subsequent career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Ham
title: Chasing the ‘Ghost Bird’ of Australia’s Outback
description: An elusive, nocturnal parrot disappeared for more than a century. An unlikely rediscovery led to ornithological scandal — and then hope.
content: There had been no confirmed sightings of a live night parrot for nearly 140 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What doctors say about Omicron
description: Doctors are telling our reporters: This Covid wave is not the same as the last.
content: We’re getting more data on Omicron’s effects on patients, this time from inside U.S. hospitals. From medical centers across the country, doctors are telling our reporters the same thing: This Covid wave seems different from the last one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Today’s Faux Pas, Tomorrow’s Lingua Franca
description: Why linguists encourage what grammarians won’t.
content: We think we know more than those who came before. Our impressions are novel, ours are the way ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Kathy Flores, Pathbreaking Women’s Rugby Coach, Dies at 66
description: She was a gifted player and exacting coach who pushed for recognition of women in a historically male-dominated sport.
content: The 1991 Women’s Rugby World Cup came down to a face-off between the brash but underdog Americans and the established England team, the product of a long British tradition in the sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Woman Suing Prince Andrew for Abuse Settled With Epstein for $500,000
description: The prince’s lawyers are expected to argue that Virginia Roberts Giuffre’s suit should be dismissed because of the earlier settlement’s terms.
content: A woman who is among Jeffrey Epstein’s most vocal accusers received $500,000 in 2009 to resolve a lawsuit in which she accused him of repeatedly sexually abusing her when she was a teenager, according to a settlement agreement unsealed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaitlyn Greenidge
title: What Does Marriage Ask Us to Give Up?
description: More and more Americans are single, living lives of hard-won independence.
content: I spent most of my 20s and 30s single, only to marry and then come to the conclusion that my marriage should end. Now I am single again. But I am not alone. My marriage ended during the pandemic, while I was at home with family. Since the pandemic began, my daughter and I have been living in what my family jokingly calls “the compound” — a house my mother and I bought together before I was married. She and my siblings and their families live there, in an attempt to withstand the waves of gentrification that have displaced everyone in my family every four to five years, as the sketchy neighborhoods we can afford get “discovered” by rich young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: 5 of the Best Sushi Restaurants in Los Angeles
description: A few of Tejal Rao’s favorites in a city swimming with stylish and skillful options.
content: Los Angeles has one of the most robust and delightful sushi scenes in the country, from vegan sushi to fusion sushi, from grocery store takeout to fine dining. If you’re looking for a truly special meal, there are countless options, but here are a few favorites that express seasonality through the mind-boggling and delicious range of their omakases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Sands of Persia Brings Elegant Desserts and Shisha to Astoria
description: A reopening for Jing Fong, a craft brewery in Newark, and more restaurant news.
content: There’s no shortage of hookah or shisha bars in Queens, but this new one, which is also a dessert destination, ramps up the luxury. It’s owned by Abhi Malhotra, who founded King Luxe Club in Westbury, N.Y., for high-end car collectors like himself, and Salil Mehta, the chef and owner of Wau, Laut and Singapura in Manhattan. Sleekly modern yet fitted with plush banquettes indoors, and additional outdoor heated seating, it offers more than 30 shisha flavors and a variety of smoking devices. A nonalcoholic drinks list includes teas and coffees, featuring Turkish coffee brewed over hot sand. Mr. Mehta’s desserts are elaborate: a yuzu cake with finger limes, meringue and orange mousse; Turkish sand coffee affogato with gold leaf; a baklava cone with pistachios and soft serve; and a sizzling brownie with soft serve. Savory plates like hummus with crudités are also available. This year, the partners will also open a three-story outpost in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, with branches in London and New Delhi to follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Office Attire That Makes a Statement: ‘OK, Let’s Hug’
description: Employers are desperate to figure out a way to safely get employees back to their desks. Enter the humble wristband.
content: Leah McGowen-Hare wants you to know one thing about her: She is a hugger. If you just met, she’ll give you a hug. If you are a Salesforce client, she’ll give you a hug. If you are considering signing up for Salesforce’s services then you, too, are in line for a hug. She extended a virtual hug in the middle of a recent video call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus and Shane O'Neill
title: Resolve to Try
description: Eight people on what they plan to dabble in this year — because making official resolutions can doom us to failure, but merely trying a new thing takes the pressure off.
content: If the last two years have taught us anything, it’s that planning leads to disappointment and inflexibility is a luxury none can afford. Amid the ongoing global pandemic, even thinking that things can improve this year can feel a little like a jinx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Be Ambivalent
description: Start by creating a list of pros and cons. It may help make you more likely to act.
content: “You can use ambivalence as a shield against the fear of rejection,” says Taly Reich, an associate professor of marketing at Yale. If you want something, like a promotion at work, say, you’ll be faced with a moment where you must decide whether to act and risk rejection or do nothing and avoid it. Reich recently published research showing that people who cultivate ambivalence are more likely to act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics: Answers to Some Big Questions
description: How will the Olympics deal with the coronavirus? What happens if athletes protest China? Will there be boycotts? Here’s what we know.
content: The 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing are right around the corner, with all kinds of questions — about international politics, public health and, yes, even sports — hanging over them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Long Story Short
description: David Bukszpan debuts with an introspective puzzle.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — We’re four puzzles into 2022, and this is our second debut of the year. Today, David Bukszpan joins the ranks of New York Times Crossword constructors with a puzzle that celebrates crossword puzzles. It’s a little unusual, in more ways than one, despite having a classic theme type.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Lisa Brodyaga, Crusading Lawyer for Immigrants’ Rights, Dies at 81
description: She became a folk hero representing asylum seekers fleeing violence in Central America, setting up shop in the Rio Grande Valley and building a refuge camp.
content: As leftist revolution and U.S.-backed counter-insurgencies spread through El Salvador and Guatemala in the early 1980s, Central America became awash in bloodshed, sending refugees fleeing to the United States border in hopes of a new life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Representative Bobby Rush, Longtime Illinois Democrat, Will Retire
description: The decision by the pastor and civil rights activist added to a wave of Democrats deciding not to run for re-election in a difficult midterm cycle.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Bobby L. Rush, the most senior Illinois House lawmaker, said on Monday that he planned to retire at the end of the year, adding to a wave of Democrats who have decided against seeking re-election in what is expected to be a tough midterm cycle for the party.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Five takeaways from the verdict in the Elizabeth Holmes trial.
description: Theranos, which dissolved in 2018, is likely to stand as a warning to other start-ups that stretch the truth to score funding and business deals.
content: Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the blood-testing start-up Theranos, was found guilty of four charges of fraud on Monday, capping a stunning fall of a prominent entrepreneur in a case that came to represent hazards of Silicon Valley’s “fake it till you make it” ethos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Azeen Ghorayshi
title: In Omicron Hot Spots, Hospitals Fill Up, but I.C.U.s May Not
description: Covid hospitalizations are surging, but a smaller proportion of cases is severe compared with previous waves. With staff shortages, some hospitals are still in crisis.
content: In hospitals around the country, doctors are taking notice: This wave of Covid seems different from the last one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: N.Y. Prisons Punished 1,600 Based on Faulty Drug Tests, Report Finds
description: Prisoners were subjected to solitary confinement and denied family visits because of improperly administered tests, the state inspector general found.
content: New York’s prison system unjustly penalized more than 1,600 incarcerated people based on faulty drug tests, putting them in solitary confinement, delaying their parole hearings and denying them family visits, the New York State inspector general said in a damning report released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Julie Turkewitz and Flávia Milhorance
title: Leftists Are Ascendant in Latin America as Key Elections Loom
description: Growing inequality and sputtering economies have helped fuel a wave of leftist victories that may soon extend to Brazil and Colombia.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — In the final weeks of 2021, Chile and Honduras voted decisively for leftist presidents to replace leaders on the right, extending a significant, multiyear shift across Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: American Crossword Puzzle Tournament Registration is Open
description: On your mark … get set … solve!
content: The 44th Annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament will be held in person on April 1-3, 2022 at the Stamford Marriott. A virtual version, without prizes, is planned to run at the same time. Covid-19 rules for the tournament will follow the latest guidance by the state of Connecticut and the city of Stamford at the time of the tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Verdict Is In on Elizabeth Holmes
description: The Theranos founder was found guilty of defrauding investors. What does that mean for Silicon Valley?
content: Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, was found guilty of fraud yesterday, in a high-profile case that came to symbolize the perils of Silicon Valley hype and hubris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Millman
title: Imagine It’s 2024, and Republicans Are Declaring Trump President
description: Too many Americans are willing to believe in election lies, and  their leaders are eager to cater to that mistaken conviction.
content: It’s Election Day 2024. President Biden and former President Donald Trump have been locked in battle for months, with Mr. Biden holding a stable, sizable lead in the popular vote but much narrower leads in key swing states like Wisconsin, Georgia and Arizona. Turnout has been exceptionally high, nearly matching 2020 levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: N.F.L.’s Week 18 Will Sort Playoff Berths
description: In the N.F.C., Green Bay has clinched the bye, but a divisional race and a wild-card spot are still up for grabs. In the A.F.C., things are messier.
content: As N.F.L. teams prepare for the newly added 17th regular-season game this weekend, some are safely in the playoffs, some are out and some are really, really out. Some are jockeying for postseason seeding. And most intriguingly, a handful of teams are facing the highest stakes of all: playing in win-or-go-home games. Here are the stakes of this weekend’s games for the teams still in the playoff mix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Vjosa Isai
title: Canada Pledges $31.5 Billion to Settle Fight Over Indigenous Child Welfare System
description: The government agreed to a landmark settlement to repair the system and compensate those families harmed by it. It potentially ends many years of litigation.
content: The Canadian government announced Tuesday that it had reached what it called the largest settlement in Canada’s history, paying $31.5 billion to fix the nation’s discriminatory child welfare system and compensate the Indigenous people harmed by it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: More quit jobs than ever, but most turnover is in low-wage work.
description: Government data for November shows the continuing disruption of the coronavirus in the labor market.
content: The number of Americans quitting their jobs is the highest on record, as workers take advantage of strong employer demand to pursue better opportunities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Malesic
title: How Men Burn Out
description: The intense public discussion of burnout during the pandemic has given too little attention to how men experience this problem.
content: Eight years ago, I had a great job as a tenured professor at a small college in Pennsylvania. I seemed to have it made: autonomy, security, excellent benefits, even a modicum of prestige. But then I started to dread going to work. The students’ indifference to my teaching felt like a personal insult. I became furious in response to minor slights from colleagues and got into heated arguments in faculty meetings. I was burning out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Macy’s requests vaccination status of all U.S. employees.
description: A memo sent to the staff indicated that the retailer was preparing for the potential that vaccines or weekly testing could be mandated by the Biden administration.
content: Macy’s began requesting the vaccination statuses of employees on Tuesday, a sign it was preparing for a potential mandate of vaccinations or weekly testing ahead of a special Supreme Court hearing about such rules on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson McCabe
title: ‘Philadelphia Freedom’ Isn’t Just a Gay Anthem. It’s a Pride Anthem.
description: Elton John’s song from 1975 resonates with me more than ever.
content: When most people think of “Philadelphia Freedom,” a single refrain comes to mind: “I lo-o-ove you/Yes I do!” They’re hard-pressed to remember the rest of the words, because as with many of Elton John’s songs, the lyrics are kind of oblique. He wrote the song in 1975 for Billie Jean King, drawing inspiration from her pioneering mixed-gender tennis team, the Philadelphia Freedoms, with a melody that nodded to the great Philly soul sounds of Gamble and Huff. But it took me decades to understand that the song wasn’t really about tennis, or Philadelphia — which is why it came to resonate so much more with me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Silicon Valley Can’t Escape Elizabeth Holmes
description: Ms. Holmes, the founder of Theranos, wasn’t a creature of Silicon Valley, or so the refrain went. But her fraud trial showed otherwise.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — In 2016, start-up founders sang, “Theranos doesn’t represent, we are better,” in a holiday video created by the venture capital firm First Round Capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: New York’s battered economy could struggle for years to come.
description: The city is not expected to rebuild its labor force to prepandemic levels until late 2025 as the recovery is hampered by a slow rebound in the leisure and hospitality sector.
content: The economic recovery in New York will continue to lag that of the United States for years, with the city not expected to rebuild its labor force to prepandemic levels until late 2025, a year later than initially projected, according to a new economic forecast by the city’s Independent Budget Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Topps will sell its sports card business to Fanatics, a rival.
description: The deal follows the loss of Topps’s licensing agreement with Major League Baseball and the Major League Baseball Players Association to Fanatics.
content: Topps, the business that put Bazooka bubble gum together with baseball cards more than half a century ago, now belongs to a fast-growing sports memorabilia empire that nearly knocked Topps out of the baseball-card game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Covid vaccinations are not linked to pre-term births, researchers report.
description: Women who were vaccinated while pregnant were at no greater risk of delivering prematurely, nor of having small babies.
content: Women who received Covid vaccinations while pregnant were at no greater risk of delivering their babies prematurely or of giving birth to unusually small babies than pregnant women who did not get vaccinated, a new study reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: What Happens When the State Controls Moms?
description: In her debut novel, “The School for Good Mothers,” Jessamine Chan imagines a future where parents (mostly women) get sent to government-run reform school.
content: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and short-story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Viral Lies That Keep Killing Us
description: Why 2021 wasn’t the year we beat the pandemic.
content: A year ago it seemed reasonable to hope that by early 2022 we’d mainly be talking about Covid — or at least Covid as a major health and quality-of-life issue — in the past tense. Effective vaccines had been developed with miraculous speed; surely a sophisticated nation like the United States would find a way to get those vaccines quickly and widely distributed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Erin Woo
title: Elizabeth Holmes is found guilty of four counts of fraud.
description: The case against the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos came to symbolize the pitfalls of Silicon Valley’s culture of hustle and hype.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, was found guilty of four of 11 charges of fraud on Monday, in a case that came to symbolize the pitfalls of Silicon Valley’s culture of hustle, hype and greed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bethany McLean
title: A Very American Question About Elizabeth Holmes and the Price of Success
description: What the Theranos trial says about the blurred lines between visionaries and frauds.
content: In his 1993 biography of Isaac Newton, Richard Westfall argues that parts of Newton’s watershed work, the Principia, are “nothing short of deliberate fraud.” True or not, it is clear that Newton made compromises in service to his vision. And he was not the only famous scientist who would do almost anything to make a breakthrough. Some would take drugs, follow mystical visions, lie and even cheat to make a discovery, as Michael Brooks notes in “Free Radicals: The Secret Anarchy of Science.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: ‘Lost & Found’ Ponders Profound Grief Alongside Newfound Love
description: Kathryn Schulz’s memoir places the totalizing experience of loss on a continuum with the summons of romantic and even religious love.
content: Since getting a booster shot from Joan Didion’s “The Year of Magical Thinking,” the grief memoir has become such a hardy genre that it deserves its own nickname — the mournmoir? the dieography? — and its own placarded table at the front of bookstores, perhaps strewn with high-profit-margin items like candles, journals and Kleenex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: The Philippines orders another wave of lockdowns amid a surge in cases.
description: The new rules bar unvaccinated residents from leaving their homes except for a list of essential reasons.
content: The Philippines announced on Tuesday that it was expanding a lockdown for unvaccinated people around the capital, Manila, after recording a spike in Covid-19 cases after the holidays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Britain can ‘ride out’ the Omicron wave without a strict lockdown, Boris Johnson says.
description: “We can find a way to live with this virus,” the prime minister said.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain on Tuesday said that despite the record surge in coronavirus cases, the limited restrictions currently in place in England were the right approach and would be maintained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: City Schools Are ‘Staying Open,’ Mayor Eric Adams Says
description: But the spike in Omicron cases has created trepidation for many parents.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at why Mayor Eric Adams is resolute about keeping public schools open as coronavirus cases skyrocket. We’ll also get a preview of Gov. Kathy Hochul’s State of the State message, which she will deliver tomorrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: A mistrial was declared for three counts in the Elizabeth Holmes trial.
description: The three hung counts were related to investments from three Theranos investors who testified that Ms. Holmes misled them.
content: A mistrial was formally declared for three counts of wire fraud against Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood-testing start-up Theranos, according to a federal court filing released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Ben Smith Is Leaving The Times for a Global News Start-Up
description: Mr. Smith will help start a new organization with Justin Smith, the chief executive of Bloomberg Media.
content: Ben Smith, the media columnist for The New York Times, is leaving the media outlet to start a new global news organization with Justin Smith, who is stepping down as chief executive of Bloomberg Media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: ‘Insurmountable’: Parents Grapple With Omicron’s Upending Force in Schools
description: Some want classrooms to stay open through the surge; others are desperate for a remote option. For nearly all, it’s an agonizing situation.
content: A mother in rural Wisconsin said she felt “utterly helpless” as she sent her 13-year-old off to school. Another, in suburban New Jersey, expressed frustration that her highly vaccinated district had returned to remote learning. One in Chicago said she hoped the city’s teachers followed through on their threat to walk out so her 12-year-old daughter wouldn’t have to return to a crowded classroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: What We Got Wrong About Tech
description: Looking back at tech misjudgments so we can better look ahead.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Ronen Bergman
title: Palestinian Prisoner’s Hunger Strike Leads to Deal for Release
description: A Palestinian accused of plotting to kill Israelis went on a hunger strike to protest his imprisonment without trial. Fearing unrest, Israel agreed to release him.
content: BEER YAAKOV, Israel — In the five-bed intensive care unit of a hospital in central Israel, ventilators and machines beeped and hummed. But there was a hushed quiet around Hisham Abu Hawash’s bed and the vital signs monitor above him was silent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: 5G cellular service will go forward as U.S. reaches deal with carriers.
description: Transportation regulators had clashed with AT&T and Verizon, saying the new technology posed a security risk.
content: Federal aviation officials have agreed not to ask for further delays to Verizon and AT&T’s new 5G cellular service, clearing the way for the companies to start their service while avoiding a major clash with regulators who said it could endanger flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Where Do Your Spices Come From?’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how cinnamon, nutmeg and cardamom are produced in Zanzibar. Then they will research a spice they are curious about.
content: This lesson is a part of our new Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: A Co-Worker Told a Sexist Joke. Should You Be Disciplined for Laughing?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how human resources should handle a reflex reaction to an inappropriate remark — and more.
content: In a company staff meeting, a regional manager made a joking remark that was unquestionably inappropriate for that setting. It was sexist in nature but quite witty and clever. While many of us in the meeting groaned in disbelief, three employees laughed out loud. The manager has been suspended by human resources. Should the people who laughed at the comment, two men and one woman, also be disciplined? Is a reflex reaction to a comment less egregious than “liking” an objectionable social media post? Name Withheld, Bedford, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: antipathy
description: This word has appeared in 61 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Olympics officials are tight-lipped on China’s abuses
description: Activists call for an inquiry into Beijing 2022 merchandise.
content: With just one month before the start of the Winter Olympics in Beijing, concerns about China’s human rights record loom over the Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Washington Football Team Plans Name Unveil Even as Bad News Mounts
description: Two days after fans at the team’s stadium fell when a railing collapsed, the team announced a Feb. 2 — Groundhog Day — launch date for its long-awaited rebranding.
content: The Washington Football Team said on Tuesday that it would unveil a new name and “identity” on Groundhog Day, Feb. 2, the culmination of an 18-month rebranding prompted by the loss of corporate sponsors that objected to the team’s former name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Djokovic is granted a medical exemption to play in the Australian Open.
description: The top-ranked player in men’s tennis revealed his plans in a post on his Instagram account.
content: Novak Djokovic, the world’s No. 1-ranked male tennis player and his sport’s most prominent vaccination skeptic, said on Tuesday that he would play in this month’s Australian Open after receiving a medical exemption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York said it needed $1 billion more for pandemic rent relief. It is getting far less.
description: The gap illustrates how severe the economic crisis has been in New York, and how aid programs may be falling short.
content: As New York State all but ran out of its share of a federal pandemic rent relief program in the fall, state officials asked the federal government for $1 billion more — money they said was necessary to keep tens of thousands of struggling residents out of debt and in their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Changing Brussels Neighborhood Tries to Leave Stigma of Terrorism Behind
description: Molenbeek was where a terrorist cell planned attacks that killed 162 in Paris and Brussels. Six years later, residents are trying to reinvent the area as a trial rekindles an awful association.
content: BRUSSELS — With children’s drawings and colorful posters now adorning the walls and windows, it was easy to forget the notorious past of the red brick building, whose history still haunts a working-class Brussels neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California’s Political Musical Chairs
description: Newly drawn congressional maps have scrambled the calculus for some incumbent lawmakers and those seeking to unseat them.
content: As 2021 drew to a close, one very important group of Californians worked feverishly to hit a very important deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Does the pandemic come with added concerns for you?
description: We’re asking readers with disabilities or who are immunocompromised to tell us about their experience.
content: Since the outbreak, readers with disabilities or who are immunocompromised have told us about the complications that they are facing. Although the world has opened up at various moments, many people have been forced to remain in lockdown, or continue to adhere to strict measures to protect themselves or their family members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: As schools confront Omicron, some choose to go remote.
description: The Omicron surge threatens to upend any sense of peace in the U.S. education system.
content: The Omicron surge threatens to upend any sense of peace in the U.S. education system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: New Hampshire’s Top Election Official Announces Retirement
description: The official, Bill Gardner, a Democrat, has served as secretary of state in New Hampshire for more than four decades.
content: Bill Gardner, who for decades as secretary of state has fiercely defended New Hampshire’s right to hold the country’s first presidential primaries, said on Monday that he would step down after 45 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Biddle Duke
title: The ‘Best Spring Skiing Anywhere’? Try Crete
description: The Greek island has no lifts, no lodges, no trail maps. But for those willing to climb for their turns, it’s got miles of wide-open terrain, dependable spring snow and no crowds.
content: From the deck of the overnight ferry from Athens, the sight of the massive snow-covered Lefka Ori range rising abruptly behind the ancient harbor town of Chania on the island of Crete, was astonishing and strangely unexpected. It was February 2020 and, accompanied by my wife, a longtime Greek friend, and the ski filmmaker Constantine Papanicolaou, I had come to Crete to ski. This took even some Cretans, who seemed oblivious to the snowy summits in plain sight, by surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Two Wyoming Bobsledders. Two Horrific Brain Injuries. One Survivor.
description: Travis Bell and Joe Sisson were close friends and rising stars in bobsled before crashes derailed their careers. Two decades later, one of them wonders why he thrived and his friend is gone.
content: MORGAN, Utah — The weeks before a Winter Olympics are always tough for Joe Sisson. It’s when he thinks most about the dream he wanted so badly, to drive a bobsled in the ultimate competition. It’s gone, and so is the friend who helped him chase it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: A federal judge blocks the Defense Dept. from punishing Navy forces who refuse the vaccine.
description: “There is no Covid-19 exception to the First Amendment. There is no military exclusion from our Constitution,” the judge said in his ruling.
content: A federal judge granted a preliminary injunction  on Monday blocking the Department of Defense from taking “any adverse action” against 35 Navy sailors who have refused to get vaccinated against the coronavirus, arguing that it violated their religious freedoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: A Long Island teacher is accused of giving a teenager a Covid shot without permission.
description: The police said the injection took place at the teacher’s home on New Year’s Eve. She is scheduled to appear in criminal court on Jan. 21.
content: A 54-year-old public-school science teacher on Long Island was arrested on New Year’s Eve after being accused of giving a teenager an injection of what appeared to be Covid-19 vaccine without his parents’ consent, the Nassau County police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Osita Nwanevu
title: Trump Isn’t the Only One to Blame for the Capitol Riot
description: Our institutions, from the Electoral College  to the media, have convinced conservatives that they are denizens of the real America.
content: In December 1972, the critic Pauline Kael admitted that she’d been living in a political bubble. “I only know one person who voted for Nixon,” she said. “Where they are, I don’t know. They’re outside my ken.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Don’t Tell Anyone, but 2021 Was Pretty Amazing
description: A closer look at a recovery for the record books.
content: Grumpy New Year! There probably weren’t many Americans who started 2022 feeling celebratory. We’re going through yet another Covid wave, which is scary and wearying even though Omicron appears to pose a relatively low risk of serious illness if you’re fully vaccinated. Holiday travel was a mess, with the combination of the pandemic and severe weather causing thousands of flight cancellations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: U.S. Charges a Suspect in Assassination of Haiti’s President
description: A former Colombian commando is the first to face U.S. prosecution in the killing of Jovenel Moïse, after agents flew him to Miami from Panama.
content: MIAMI — The United States has charged a retired Colombian commando with taking part in the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti — the first suspect to face U.S. prosecution in the crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: A Frazzled America Staggers Into 2022
description: The Omicron variant’s spread poses an unwelcome political conundrum just as election season begins. Democrats and the G.O.P. see reasons to hope, but the virus will get the deciding vote.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the political news in Washington and across the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sunny Hostin
title: A Debut Novel About Friendship, Family and Other Ties That Bind
description: In “Brown Girls,” Daphne Palasi Andreades breaks a big world into small, meaningful pieces.
content: BROWN GIRLSBy Daphne Palasi Andreades
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: No Way to Grow Up
description: For the past two years, Americans have accepted more harm to children in exchange for less harm to adults.
content: American children are starting 2022 in crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Is the Bravest Thing You’ve Ever Done?
description: A sixth grader in Oklahoma saved two lives in one day. Tell us about a time you showed courage in the face of a challenge.
content: Have you ever been in a situation that required bravery? What were the circumstances? Did you take action?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Beukes
title: A Gothic Novel Haunted by Nine Lives Over Nine Decades
description: In “Luckenbooth,” Jenni Fagan traces the strange, fantastical stories of artists, vagabonds, dreamers and mystics in a single tenement.
content: LUCKENBOOTHBy Jenni Fagan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: The Epic Rise and Fall of Elizabeth Holmes
description: In Silicon Valley’s world of make-believe, the philosophy of “fake it until you make it” finally gets its comeuppance.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Near the end of Elizabeth Holmes’s criminal trial, her lawyers submitted into evidence her punishing self-improvement plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Only 17% of workers say their pay has kept pace with inflation.
description: A survey shows a vast majority of Americans across party lines are concerned about the rise in prices.
content: Wages are rising at their fastest pace in years, but prices are rising even faster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Ireland Puts Minimum Price on Alcohol to Curb Binge Drinking
description: The new rule, part of broader legislation aimed at stemming alcohol-related illnesses, sets a minimum price of one euro per standard drink and came into effect on Tuesday.
content: Ireland’s government imposed a minimum unit price on alcoholic beverages on Tuesday, one of a few nations to introduce such a rule as a public health measure intended to curb binge drinking and reduce alcohol-related health issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Petition to Rescind Tony Blair’s Knighthood Gets Hundreds of Thousands of Signatures
description: Nearly 15 years after he left office, the prime minister’s support for the Iraq war has not been forgiven by many in Britain.
content: LONDON — By tradition, former British prime ministers are honored by Queen Elizabeth some years after leaving 10 Downing Street, so the elevation of Tony Blair to a knighthood on New Year’s Day could have been a routine event.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Letter From the Albany County D.A.
description: David Soares, the Albany County district attorney, said his office could not successfully prosecute the case against Andrew M. Cuomo.
content: David Soares, the Albany County district attorney, said his office could not successfully prosecute the case against Andrew M. Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: By weight, how much of you is carbon?
description: Answer this question to learn a bit about what you’re made of.
content: Answer this question to learn a bit about what you’re made of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Spanish Police Seize 300,000 Unauthorized Covid Tests
description: The police in Spain released a video showing the seizure of unauthorized antigen tests from a warehouse on Dec. 29. Amid a national shortage of coronavirus test kits, the police are investigating cases of theft or illegal trafficking of hundreds of thousands of the tests.
content: The police in Spain released a video showing the seizure of unauthorized antigen tests from a warehouse on Dec. 29. Amid a national shortage of coronavirus test kits, the police are investigating cases of theft or illegal trafficking of hundreds of thousands of the tests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: ‘We May Need Even More’: Biden Doubles Pfizer’s Covid Pills Order
description: President Biden announced that the United States government doubled its order for Pfizer’s Covid pills, bringing the total order to 20 million treatment courses.
content: President Biden announced that the United States government doubled its order for Pfizer’s Covid pills, bringing the total order to 20 million treatment courses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and The Associated Press
title: Snowstorm Strands Drivers Overnight on I-95
description: A snowstorm left drivers stranded on Interstate 95 near Fredericksburg, Va., for more than 24 hours.
content: A snowstorm left drivers stranded on Interstate 95 near Fredericksburg, Va., for more than 24 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: Election Falsehoods Surged on Podcasts Before Capitol Riots, Researchers Find
description: A new study analyzed nearly 1,500 episodes, showing the extent to which podcasts pushed misinformation about voter fraud.
content: Weeks before the 2020 presidential election, the conservative broadcaster Glenn Beck outlined his prediction for how Election Day would unfold: President Donald J. Trump would be winning that night, but his lead would erode as dubious mail-in ballots arrived, giving Joseph R. Biden Jr. an unlikely edge.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mental Health on College Campuses Amid Covid
description: Student suicides, a shortage of counselors and stories of resilience. Also: Just one Republican; guardianship abuse; spouses’ love-hate relationships.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 4, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 4, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about the “Jeopardy!” contestant Amy Schneider misstated the year in which Ken Jennings won 74 consecutive games on “Jeopardy!” It was 2004, not 2014.
source.name: The New York Times
